overview: David Cameron announced EU reform deal and set referendum date for 23 June 2016
furtherDescription: Prime Minister David Cameron delivered a statement in the House of Commons outlining the four areas of EU reform he had negotiated (economic governance, competitiveness, sovereignty, and immigration) and formally announced that the referendum on UK's EU membership would be held on 23 June 2016. This marked the official beginning of the referendum campaign period.

overview: Cameron argued that the referendum decision was bigger than a general election
furtherDescription: In a speech at O2 plc in Slough, Prime Minister Cameron told business employees that the referendum decision was 'much bigger' than ordinary elections because it would shape the country's future for decades. He emphasized the economic benefits of EU membership and warned against the uncertainties of leaving.

overview: Liz Truss warned farmers that leaving EU would be a 'leap into the dark'
furtherDescription: As Environment Secretary, Liz Truss (who later became Prime Minister) told farmers to vote Remain, emphasizing UK access to the EU's 500 million consumers and warning of potential trade barriers. She highlighted that agricultural subsidies under the Common Agricultural Policy made up roughly 50-60% of UK farm income and that Brexit would bring huge uncertainty to farming policy.

overview: CBI warned Brexit could cost UK economy £100bn and 950,000 jobs by 2020
furtherDescription: The Confederation of British Industry commissioned research showing a potential 3-5% hit to GDP and major job losses if the UK left the EU. The CBI's analysis projected that leaving would blow a £100 billion hole in the economy and result in nearly a million job losses. This became widely cited evidence by the Remain campaign.

overview: Remain campaign published £9.3m government leaflet warning of 'decade of uncertainty'
furtherDescription: Britain Stronger in Europe (the official Remain campaign) published a government-funded leaflet costing £9.3 million that was delivered to households across the UK. The leaflet argued that Brexit would raise living costs, hit jobs, reduce living standards, and lead to 'a decade or more of uncertainty'. The use of public funds for this campaign material was controversial.

overview: Vote Leave officially designated as lead Leave campaign
furtherDescription: The Electoral Commission designated Vote Leave as the official campaign for leaving the European Union, led by Conservative politicians including Boris Johnson and Michael Gove. This gave Vote Leave access to higher spending limits, broadcast time, and official campaign materials. The rival Leave.EU campaign, associated with Nigel Farage and UKIP, failed to secure the designation.

overview: Nigel Farage claimed Brexit would allow UK to take back control of its borders
furtherDescription: UKIP leader Nigel Farage made border control and immigration a central message of the Leave campaign, arguing that EU membership prevented the UK from controlling who entered the country. This 'take back control' message became one of the most resonant themes of the Brexit campaign, focusing heavily on concerns about immigration levels.

overview: HM Treasury published analysis claiming Brexit would cost households £4,300 per year
furtherDescription: The Treasury analysis estimated that voting to leave would make each UK household on average £4,300 worse off per year after 15 years, based on a projected GDP reduction of 6.2% and a tax increase equivalent to 8p on the basic rate of income tax. This analysis was heavily criticized by Leave campaigners as 'Project Fear'.

overview: Barack Obama warned UK would be 'back of the queue' for US trade deals
furtherDescription: During a state visit to the UK, US President Barack Obama intervened in the referendum debate, warning that Britain would be 'at the back of the queue' for trade deals with the United States if it left the EU. His use of the British term 'queue' rather than American 'line' sparked controversy, with Leave supporters accusing him of being coached by Downing Street.

overview: David Cameron argued leaving EU would threaten national security
furtherDescription: Prime Minister Cameron suggested that EU membership allowed Britain to work more closely with European allies against terrorism and other security threats. He argued that cooperation through EU institutions like Europol made the UK safer and that leaving would weaken Britain's ability to combat international crime and terrorism.

overview: Vote Leave highlighted potential trade deals with non-EU countries
furtherDescription: Leave campaigners argued that outside the EU, the UK would be free to negotiate its own trade agreements with non-EU countries, including fast-growing economies like China and India. They claimed the UK was being held back by the EU's cumbersome collective trade negotiation process and could secure better deals independently.

overview: Boris Johnson argued EU was undermining British democracy
furtherDescription: Former London Mayor Boris Johnson framed Brexit as reclaiming democracy, arguing that decisions affecting Britain should not be made by unelected EU bureaucrats in Brussels. He claimed the EU was a threat to self-government and that British laws should be made by British parliamentarians accountable to British voters.

overview: Michael Gove said Brexit would restore sovereignty to UK Parliament
furtherDescription: Justice Secretary Michael Gove claimed too many decisions were being made in Brussels rather than Westminster. In a campaign rally, he asserted that the UK would 'take back control' of approximately £19 billion a year (equivalent to £350 million a week) if it left the EU. Sovereignty and parliamentary supremacy became core Leave campaign messages.

overview: Remain campaign emphasized freedom of movement benefits for young people
furtherDescription: The Remain campaign argued that staying in the EU guaranteed British citizens the right to work, study, and travel across Europe without visas or work permits. They particularly emphasized the opportunities this provided for young people to study abroad through Erasmus and work across 28 countries.

overview: Remain campaign warned of house price falls and job losses from Brexit
furtherDescription: Opponents of Brexit argued that leaving would destabilize the housing market and increase unemployment. Economic modeling suggested property values could fall significantly and that businesses would cut jobs or relocate to continental Europe. Critics labeled this strategy 'Project Fear'.

overview: Chancellor Osborne warned of 'DIY recession' if Britain left EU
furtherDescription: Chancellor George Osborne warned voters that Brexit would cause an immediate economic shock and push the UK into a self-inflicted 'DIY recession'. The Treasury published analysis suggesting GDP would shrink, unemployment would rise, and the pound would fall sharply. Leave campaigners dismissed these warnings as alarmist.

overview: UK Statistics Authority criticized £350m per week claim as misleading
furtherDescription: The UK Statistics Authority officially criticized the Vote Leave campaign's claim that the UK sends £350 million per week to the EU, calling it misleading. In a public statement, the Authority noted that the gross figure ignored the UK's rebate and funds returned to the UK, and warned that misuse of statistics undermines public trust in official data.

overview: Vote Leave campaign claimed leaving EU would save £350 million per week for NHS
furtherDescription: The Vote Leave campaign prominently featured the claim on their battle bus that leaving the EU would save £350 million per week which could be spent on the NHS instead. This figure, which ignored the UK's rebate and EU funding received, became one of the most controversial and widely-discussed claims of the referendum campaign. It was later criticized as misleading by fact-checkers and the UK Statistics Authority.

overview: FTSE 100 fell 2% as polls showed Brexit becoming more likely
furtherDescription: Financial markets reacted nervously to polling suggesting increased support for Leave. The FTSE 100 index lost £98 billion in value in a single day, falling by 2%. The pound also weakened against major currencies. Subsequent polls suggesting a move back towards Remain led to a recovery, illustrating the market volatility during the final weeks of the campaign.

overview: Nigel Farage unveiled controversial 'Breaking Point' immigration poster
furtherDescription: UKIP leader Nigel Farage unveiled a controversial poster showing a queue of refugees and migrants at the Slovenia-Croatia border in 2015 under the headline 'Breaking Point' and the slogan 'The EU has failed us all'. The poster was widely condemned across the political spectrum, with Chancellor George Osborne calling it 'disgusting and vile' with 'echoes of literature used in the 1930s'. Even Leave campaigner Michael Gove said he 'shuddered' when he saw it. The poster was part of a £100,000 campaign and was reported to police for alleged incitement of racial hatred.

overview: Labour MP Jo Cox murdered by white supremacist in Birstall
furtherDescription: Labour MP Jo Cox, a prominent Remain supporter and advocate for Syrian refugees, was shot and stabbed multiple times outside a library in Birstall, West Yorkshire, where she was about to hold a constituency surgery. Her attacker, Thomas Mair, was a 53-year-old white supremacist with Nazi sympathies who shouted 'Britain first' during the attack. Cox died shortly after at Leeds General Infirmary. Both referendum campaigns immediately suspended activities as a mark of respect. The killing was later ruled an act of terrorism, and Mair was sentenced to life imprisonment. The murder shocked the nation and temporarily changed the tone of the referendum debate, with Jo Cox's husband Brendan stating she had been deeply troubled by the divisive tone of the campaign.

overview: Referendum campaigns suspended following Jo Cox murder
furtherDescription: Following the murder of Jo Cox, both the Remain and Leave campaigns suspended all activities for a second day as a mark of respect. Prime Minister David Cameron cancelled a planned rally in Gibraltar. The BBC cancelled political programmes including Question Time and This Week. A minute's silence was observed across the UK. Campaigning resumed on 19 June, with politicians calling for a more respectful tone in the final days before the vote.

overview: Referendum day: UK voted to leave the European Union by 51.9% to 48.1%
furtherDescription: The United Kingdom held a referendum on continued EU membership, with 51.89% voting to leave and 48.11% voting to remain. Turnout was 72.2%, one of the highest for any UK vote. England and Wales voted to leave (except London), while Scotland, Northern Ireland, and Gibraltar voted to remain. The result was unexpected by many pollsters and financial markets. Sterling hit a 2016 high of $1.5018 early on referendum day based on exit polls suggesting Remain would win, but when the Sunderland result showed an unexpected swing to Leave, the pound plummeted to $1.3777, its lowest level since 1985.

overview: David Cameron announced resignation as Prime Minister
furtherDescription: Following the Leave vote, Prime Minister David Cameron announced his resignation outside 10 Downing Street, saying 'I don't think it would be right for me to try to be the captain that steers our country to its next destination.' He said he would remain in post until October to allow the Conservative Party to choose a successor. The pound fell to a 31-year low of $1.32 when markets opened on Monday. The Bank of England pledged to support the financial system amid market turmoil.
